headline: Great Company to work for
status:
19 February 2020
Helpful (1)
"Great Company to work for"
5.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: Company truly cares about employees. They show that by flying you to the headquarters for training to inform you about their culture. Also a fabulous steak dinner on the last night to socialize with others.
cons: I don't have any cons about this company

headline: Needs better re-investment in the employees
pros: Good resources, training available for other positions, but not sure if it will lead to a promotion or not as I was not there long enough.
cons: Benefits are lack-luster. Would have like to have seen a re-investment in the employee, such as 401k matching. This was one of the reasons I left the company.

headline: Doesn’t value employees
status:
10 February 2020
Helpful (1)
"Doesn’t value employees"
2.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: The pay was decent and the employees were great people.
cons: No opportunities for annual raises, and no bonuses. They take top producers and execs on an extravagant trip Mexico, neglecting to realize that helping those top producers is a team effort. The company brings in billions, yet refuses to reward the employees who show up every day to support its success.
advice_to_mgmt: If you want to retain and recruit top talent, consider rewarding your employees with a bonus, annual raise, or even just a 401k match. You can’t expect to keep up with other companies if you don’t value your people.

headline: Love my branch
status:
9 October 2019
"Love my branch"
5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: I've been here 7+ years, and have always had a great relationship with my boss. Richard is super flexible and has always pretty much let me do what I want/need as far as leaving to take care of my daughter when she was still at home. I recently had an offer from another employer for considerably higher base pay, and he matched it. Shows that he values me as an employee.
cons: I know that at the Corporate level, they allow people to work from home - wish this were an option for me at the Branch level. Would love to telecommute a couple days a week.
advice_to_mgmt: not really a lot of room for advancement at the branch level. would consider moving into Underwriting, but know that when layoffs come around, I'd be first out the door, and I wouldn't have the security that I do at my Branch.

headline: Great Company
status:

"Great Company"
4.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: Great Company with great Executive Management team.
cons: No advancement opportunities and no annual reviews for raises.
advice_to_mgmt: Thank you for your review.

headline: Great work environment with work-life balance
pros: CCMC provides a great, family-like culture and encourages employees to have work-life balance. The company has a longstanding positive reputation in the community and it's wonderful to hear about CCMC's customer-focused mission to help home owners.
cons: It would really enhance the benefits if the company provided a 401k match and some form of paid family leave.

headline: Great Team. Great Culture.
status:
20 June 2019
"Great Team. Great Culture."
5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros:
• I love the team I work with! They are more than just my co-workers but more like my friends or work family.
• The VP of Marketing, David Arrnet is AMAZING! I always feel listened to and supported. He is also great at encouraging a work-life balance and really helps continue to grow and push our team to do the best we can.
cons:
• Communication between different departments is not always clear or even there which can make it difficult when working on bigger initiatives
• Benefits (mainly no matching on 401K) are not the best
• You can't bring your dog to work
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to not only the managers but also the people who may be at the "bottom of the barrel". They have ideas and see things that you may not.

headline: Great Culture and Work Life Balance
status:

5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: Love the company, the vibe around corporate and the accessibility of most of the executive leadership.
cons: Sometimes corporate moves slowly, but that's the way it is with most companies.

headline: I love my job and my CCMC Family.
status:
6 June 2019
"I love my job and my CCMC Family."
5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros:
Fantastic leadership that really listens to their employees and is not afraid to try new ideas. 
Culture is like a big family. 
Incredible opportunities for growth, increasing education and sharpening skills. 
Forward thinking and striving for cutting-edge technologies.
A good work/life balance is promoted.
cons: 401 K is not a match; however, we do have a home loan benefit that is fantastic.

headline: Branch Manager
status:
27 April 2019
"Branch Manager"
4.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: The newly launched, proprietary LOS system is by far the best in the industry. Management provides loan officers business development tools like Home Buyers Marketing, MBS, OSI and MBS Highway. We have an in-house coaching program through Rewire and an annual sales rally. Programs are constantly being added to provide loan officers opportunities to assist more buyers. Management is accessible and responsive.
cons: Some departments provide better service than others. Brand awareness outside of the Colorado market is less than desirable. No matched 401k.
advice_to_mgmt: Share your vision and plans for the future growth of the company. Where are we going and how are you going to get us there? Take the time to visit your branches. Survey employees, you might be surprised at the insights you are able to glean.

headline: Run from this company
status:
23 April 2019
"Run from this company"
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: There were a few decent folks.
cons: Worst company I ever worked for. Within a month of leaving, management handed my closed loan client base to someone and told them to solicit my clients. Mind you, these were self sourced clients and mgmt told me prior to starting there that they would never solicit my clients. They also have a horrendous underwriting dept. Closing a loan here was worth than walking through a swamp filled with alligators.
advice_to_mgmt: Don’t Lie to your employees. Practice what you preach.

headline: Like a Family
status:
15 January 2019
"Like a Family"
5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: Everyone really cares about you and wants you to succeed. They have great technology and corporate is designed to make life easier for LO's.
cons: Do not think it is a great time to be in the industry, with rising rates and high home prices many people are priced out and there is practically no Refi business to be found.
advice_to_mgmt: Maybe figure out a way to drive some leads to LO's.

headline: Non-exempt position
pros: Pay was acceptable, majority of leads/mgrs very good about anyone needing personal time/making up time.
cons: Male employees paid more for same positions than female employees. Nepotism present, standing up to alleged mistreatment frowned upon .
advice_to_mgmt: End the denial of potential corruption and nepotism, it will most likely ultimately harm your company's success.

headline: Does not pay equally for same work
status:
12 February 2018
"Does not pay equally for same work"
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: The office space is nice.
cons:
Not all loan officers are paid equally. Different commission structure for different people, not based on experience, but based on who recruited you. New LOs with small production are paid a higher percentage than seasoned LOs who were hired on their own without a recruiter. 

Manager pays commissions late. I was paid 30 days past my contract date, more than once. (60 days past loan closing) You have to hound them to get paid.
advice_to_mgmt: Treat all LOs equally. Pay commissions on time.

headline: Terrible management! Great pay!
status:
20 August 2017
Helpful (1)
"Terrible management! Great pay!"
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: If you're looking for a good pay day and literally have no other cares in the world... this is the place for you!
cons: No 401k Match. The management team is full of children. The technology is terrible and they refuse to acknowledge it, you just have to pretend everything is great. They recently got sued for failing to provide health insurance to a same sex couple. You should expect to stay in the same position you're hired in... forever. If you indicate to management you want to grow your career they'll pat your back and send you back to your desk. This place is run terribly because the executive management team is a joke and the President is clueless so it's not likely to change anytime soon.
advice_to_mgmt: Get rid of most of your executive management team! They have no idea what they are doing anyways...

headline: Strong Colorado Company - but needs to be a little more consistent
pros: Local company, good benefits, many branch locations, upper management is friendly. CEO and VPs are visible and engage with their staff and engaged in the business.
cons: There's some disconnect between various departments. The management doesn't always enforce policies they've set up consistently.
advice_to_mgmt: Enforce rules and policies consistently or not at all.

headline: Amazing Company to Work For
pros: This is a company that understands that taking care of your employees leads to happy customers. Their values and desire to do the most transparent and honest business made it a company I could get on board with. It is apparent why they have grown so large, as their commitment to hiring individuals of integrity and screening processes during hiring demonstrate. In an industry where anyone with a pulse can get hired with no regards to the consumers experience, Cherry Creek has really excelled at separating themselves from that stigma. I have never worked for a mortgage company that focuses so hard on helping employees have life balance, even to the extent of investing in career growth curriculum and life coaching for the employee. Most of the employees have been here for a long time with hopes of never leaving, and I can see why.
cons: I can't think of any.

headline: Loan Officer
pros: Great people!!!! Very supportive staff!!!
cons: No coaching/ ongoing training program within the company.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work!

headline: Non existent management
status:
9 October 2014
"Non existent management"
2.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: Very kind people working there with good intentions
cons: The person that actually knows the business and you can respect is never there and the person he left in charge was his best friend who has no clue about the business. Internally he was made fun of as the No man because of ignorance he just said no to any loan that wasn't a cookie cutter loan not because he meant it but because he feared it biting him in the butt from lack of knowledge of the business and industry. Processing needs an attitude adjustment, everyone in the office is related or friends, it was almost like walking into a cult
advice_to_mgmt: Hire without fear to bring in experienced knowledge people and allow room for change with the time. When there is a problem with your staff that has been there for a long time, listen, maybe that's why your not growing

headline: Productive, sometimes stressful, rewarding.
status:
5 August 2014
"Productive, sometimes stressful, rewarding."
4.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: Helping those looking for mortgages to better understand the process can be very rewarding. It's a real team environment where people work together to get the job done. The atmosphere is typically friendly, helpful and results driven.
cons: There much on the job training rather than formal training, especially for lower levels of management.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on training new managers on policies and regulations in dealing with their team.

headline: Opportunity Knocks
status:
14 July 2014
"Opportunity Knocks"
5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: As an employee, I feel a tremendous amount of support from Cherry Creek Mortgage and its executive team. In my experience, there is a very open line of communication between myself and my boss, and he is very receptive to my ideas and provides me the support I need to move forward with the projects that I'm tasked to lead.
cons: The mortgage industry is very dynamic and requires you to be adaptable to change. CCMC's management team is very responsive to industry trends and regulatory pressures, so this means that, as an employee, you have to be flexible and willing to adjust at those times when the company's focus changes from one directive to another. I think that this same critique could be applied to any mortgage company that is looking to survive and thrive within the current industry environment.
advice_to_mgmt: We have branches spread across a large number of states. I'd love to see an initiative that supports and strengthens our "culture" across those branches, so that those in corporate have a better feel for what is happening at the branch level and vice versa.

headline: Hurry up and wait for mgmt
status:
22 April 2014
Helpful (3)
"Hurry up and wait for mgmt"
3.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: Cherry Creek is a friendly, laid back place to work, with flexible managers, and a dedicated staff of people at corporate who take their job seriously and work extremely hard to support loan originators in the field.
cons: It seems like the strategy for business development is changed on a weekly basis. Low follow through on initiatives by upper mgmt, and it seems like the corporate staff is caught in a cycle of scrambling to keep up. Low career mobility.
advice_to_mgmt: Set a goal, tell the company about it, know how your going to reach it, then do it! Enough of the "well lets see how this goes" mentality!

headline: Great employee treatment

cons: some of the benefits don't trickle down to branches outside of corporate main area in Colorado. Communication is lacking between departments. Lots of resources are not actually available outside of Colorado.
advice_to_mgmt: Make resources equal among all branches.

headline: Horrible senior management
status:
25 November 2012
"Horrible senior management"
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: Few pros but the compensation is competitive.
cons: Company portrays itself as a very balanced and focused company. It is not. The basic communications are astonishingly awful. The company will send out 25 page emails and expect everyone just to know everything. Anyone ever hear of a memo and an archive on an intranet? Additionally, they care about sales, not customers.
advice_to_mgmt: Get in touch. Originate every once and a while. Communicate more effectively and have a place where previous communications can be accessed.
